data: COMPACT BIOPHOTONIC PLATFORM FOR DRUG ALLERGY DIAGNOSIS

Drug hypersensitivity to antibiotics, mainly Beta-lactams (BLCs) affects more than 2.5 million European citizens. Moreover, preventable adverse drug reactions are estimated in additional hospitalization costs of 1750-4500 €/patient. Currently, the allergy diagnosis is mainly based on the information given by invasive, single, and risky in vivo assays. In daily practice, few in vitro diagnostic methods are available and only used at the tertiary health services. These tests also lack of sensitivity (>0.35 kUA/L) and selectivity (<98%), resulting in an inaccurate diagnosis, analyze few drugs allergens (5), are time consuming (60-180 min), and expensive (30 €/allergen).

COBIOPHAD aims the development of an innovative in vitro diagnostic (IVD) device for diagnosis of IgE-mediated drug allergies by building an integrated biophotonic system based on compact disc technology. For that, key enabling technologies will be integrated in order to achieve high sensitive (<0.1 kUA/L), selective (>98%), multiplexed (10 BLCs), rapid (30 min), and low-cost (2.4 €/allergen) drug allergy test. The solution involves an advanced approach to the diagnosis and management of drug allergy with the aim to ameliorate patient safety. 

The consortium comprises multidisciplinary knowledge on optics, electronics, advanced materials, biotechnology, smart microstructures, microfluidics, surface/organic chemistry, allergy, manufacturing systems, and telecom networking. Also, the key industrial actors, present in the consortium, will contribute to the manufacturing and placing the product on the IVD market.

The consortium has worked strategically with internationalization for many years. The cooperation shows that the mobility projects assist the students in determining their choice of education as well as retaining them at college and ensuring they exploit their full learning potential. The strategic goal of the consortium for the period 2015-2020 is to increase the coherence between the topics English and cross-cultural understanding in our international activities.

Vocational Education and Training Programme (EUX):
An important part of the project is to increase the activities, and consequently EUX-Business apply for 45 mobilities for the period 2018-2019 and another 45 mobilities for 2019-2020. During the past two years, we have developed a programme together with Intuition London and City College Brighton where the curriculum has been transferred into a British context focusing on the topics Cross-cultural Studies and Marketing. The programme meets the learning objectives for the two topics as defined by the Ministry of Education. Furthermore, the students will be working with practical assignments and cases, just as they will be cooperating with students from Barnet & Southgate College and Brighton City College respectively. In addition to this, they will be doing one week of training in local companies. The progression of the programme will be accelerated through the shift between theory and practical assignments in a foreign context and a foreign language.

An important part of the mobility project is to encourage students to train abroad, for instance via the Training Abroad Programme. The Europe 2020 Strategy dictates, “before 2020 an average of at least 6 per cent of the 18 to 34 years’ olds who have completed the basic VET programme must have studies or trained (including outplacements) at least two weeks or less if documented by a Europass”. The mobility is placed during the students’ second year to ensure that they can prepare, integrate and process the competences acquired abroad are projected in their future studies, exams, and search for apprenticeship positions as well as encouraging lifelong learning and mobility.
At the moment, the consortium is not planning to take on incoming mobility. The implementation of the new VET reforms is extremely time consuming and the consortium is under the impression that it will cause great difficulties finding British students who match the theoretical levels of the EUX, and we must ensure the quality of the mobility projects before taking on incoming mobility.

The Higher Commercial Examination Programme (HHX):
After many years of experience from VET in acquiring language skills and cross-cultural understanding, AABC now wishes to extend the Erasmus+ programme to include the HHX. Consequently, we apply for two flows of 25 students for three-week mobilities in Brighton in cooperation with Greater Brighton Metropolitan College (GBMC); 25 mobilities for the period 2018 to 2019 and 25 mobilities for the period 2019 to 2020. These students, all of great academic potential, have chosen the Global Marketing Programme at AABC where topics such as Marketing and International Economics are taught in English. At GBMC,  theory will be supported by at least one week of training in relevant, local companies, thus increasing the students’ language skills, cross-cultural understanding and insight. The practical and real-life work experiences constitute the core of the academic progression during the mobility as well as after where it will be included in classes back in Denmark. 
 
The mobility projects at EUX-Business and HHX increase the focus on internationalisation among faculty at the colleges and when students return to college with a new and larger perspective, faculty competences must be developed too. Therefore, we wish to extend the period the accompanying teachers usually stay in London and Brighton to cover the entire period of the mobilities, i.e., teachers staying end to end, one week at the time, rather than a couple of days as in previous years. Faculty will be there to support our students, and will also participate in classes, and visit students when they are training in companies. This will boost the language skills of our faculty and develop their cross-cultural competences, which they can implement in classes upon their return to Denmark, thus contributing to emphasizing the international perspective of our programmes.
Sprog, kulturforståelse og arbejdsbaseret læring KNORD 2018-2020

HHX:

The participants in the project are 3rd year students at HHX. The students are taught by British teachers at the partner school and the topics are defined by us and targeted the HHX curriculum. 

Learning content/learning outcome:
The topics taught are: The UK political system, Immigration/culture and literature, the relation to the EU, industrial relations and the financial situation in the UK.

Furthermore, the students are taught grammar, especially within areas which are difficult for Danish students such as word order, tense, prepositions, the use of the verb to do, and vocabulary for the work placements. The participating students are accommodated with British families (homestay). Thereby, the students have the opportunity to make use of their language abilities both in the families and in the local community as well as experience the multicultural British culture. 

As the exchange stay is both a study and a work placement with homestay, the students have the opportunity to improve both their oral, communicative, intercultural and personal competences.

For HHX-students, work placements in companies are highly relevant and important in order for the students to acquire commercial understanding and knowledge about British companies. The internships will primarily be in offices and hotel receptions and in some cases as shop assistants in retail. 

It is a target for our school to strengthen the international dimension in the education and strengthen the students’ ability to function in an international work environment. Moreover, the students’ understanding of foreign cultures will be improved, which in itself is both positive and useful. Furthermore, such an exchange stay will be of use for the students if they choose to study abroad later on in life.


The study and work placement exchanges will take place within three weeks in October/November 2018 and October/November 2019. The students will study and work in London. They will go to school for 1 week and will be in work placements for 2 weeks. During the school period, obligatory cultural activities are planned in the afternoon. 

After a three-week exchange stay in the UK, the students will return with a learning outcome in various areas. Fx increased vocabulary, greater knowledge of the UK society and intercultural competences but also with a personal gain from which they will profit in future.

EUX:

Mobility exchange for EUX students specializing within retail, businesses and offices:

The purpose of this project is to send students to Gower College Swansea, Wales, UK and students to London, UK and Dublin, Ireland in the school years 2018-2020.

All mobility exchanges for EUX students consist of one or two weeks’ school and one or two weeks’ work placements within retail, businesses and offices. All mobility exchanges are for three weeks. 

The mobility exchange with our Welsh partner is based on a mutual mobility exchange. First, the Welsh students will visit KNORD. Here they will participate in the lessons with students at KNORD and finish the exchange with two weeks’ work placement. Half a year later, KNORDs’ students will visit Gower College Swansea where they will participate in the lessons for two weeks and then they will have one-week  work placements. 

The purpose of the mobility exchanges is to strengthen the students’ oral and international competences which is part of the students’ curriculum applying to the EUX education.  The EUX curriculum also focusses on developing and strengthening the students’ international competences.

The overall purpose is to strengthen the international dimension of the EUX education at KNORD and thereby motivate the students to become more international and see the possibilities for potential apprenticeships and jobs around the world.

The mobility exchanges focus on the oral competences and also to strengthen the students’ English competences. English is a topic the students must take at the EUX education and at a very high level. During the mobility exchange stays, the students will improve their intercultural competences and get vocational experience from another country.

The focus on internationalization will contribute to preparing the students for a job and they will become more able to compete when they apply for apprenticeships in a time where apprenticeships are few. The project will add a European dimension to EUX at Knord.

English teachers at both EUX and HHX at Knord wish to train their linguistic competences by taking courses at Gover College in Wales. Moreover, they would like to observe native teachers of English and get an insight into the digital teaching material used in the education at Gover College Swansea.

Our colleges have worked strategically with internationalisation for many years. The cooperation shows that the mobility projects assist the students in determining their choice of education as well as retaining them at college. The strategic goal of the consortium for 2015-2020 is to increase the international activities, and we are applying for 35 student mobilities in 2016-2017 and 50 in 2017-2018. However, as a result of recent reforms of VET, the quality has to meet the new learning objectives defined by the Ministry. We are developing a programme together with Intuition London (copy enclosed) where the Danish curriculum is transferred to a British context focusing on Cross-cultural Studies and Marketing. Apart from the curriculum, students will be working on practical assignments, cases and cooperating with British students from Barnet & Southgate College and Brighton City College respectively, just as they will be doing one week of training in companies in London or Brighton. An important part of the mobility project is to encourage students’ to train abroad, for instance through the Work Placement Abroad Programmme. The Europe 2020 strategy dictates that ‘before 2020 an average of at least 6 per cent of the 18 to 34 years’ olds who have completed the basic VET programme  must have studied or trained (including outplacements) at least two weeks or less if documented by a Europas’. The mobility is placed during the students’ second year to ensure that they can prepare, integrate and process the competences achieved during the mobility project in their further studies and training.  Experience shows that the competences acquired abroad are projected in their future studies, exams and search for apprenticeships as well as encourages lifelong learning and mobility. At the moment, the consortium is not planning to take on incoming mobility. The implementation of the new VET reforms is extremely time consuming and the consortium does not wish to put any further work pressure on the colleges.  We need to ensure that quality of the mobility projects before taking on incoming mobility.  The mobility projects increase the focus on internationalisation within the colleges and when students return to college with a new and larger perspective, staff competences must be developed too. Therefore, we wish to send 2 teachers 2 weeks at the time, one after the other, to the destinations, rather than just a couple of days as in previous years. The teachers will support our students during the entire stay, but will also participate in classes and visit students during the work training. This way, the teachers will develop their English profiency and gain new cross-cultural competences which they can implement in their classes upon their return and thereby assist in raising the bar of international perspective of vocational education.With regard to internationalization, Aarhus Business College and Tietgen cooperate strategically with Aalborg Handelsskole (AH), including curriculum, couse contents and preperation of students. As AH still has not have a Charter, AH applies for mobility funding on their own.Due to the increased focus on staff competences we are applying for 8 staff mobilities, 6 at the Higher Commercial Examination Programme (HHX) and 2 at the main course of VET. At HHX, many students wish to improve the possibility of being admitted into one of the international profiles at a Danish University or to a University abroad. To meet this demand, HHX has developed a new profile Global Marketing where Marketing and Cross-cultural Studies are being taught in English. Year 2013 graduate this summer and next year, HHX will be boasting six classes of this very popular profile. Therefore, teachers’ linguistic skills and proficiency, cultural insight and understanding of the labour market in a European and global context are vital.  Teachers in Marketing and Cross-cultural Studies often hold an MA in Economics, European Studies, History of Ideas etc. and are familiar with the English terminology, but their proficiency is lacking.  The purpose of offering this group of teachers English courses is the ensure that they gain the English proficiency required to teach at the level defined by the Ministry. The Main Course of VET has signed a contract with the Danish transport company DSV that wished to offer their European trainees the same education within Shipping as their Danish trainees. The teachers all have a background within shipping and they too are familiar with the English terminology within their field, but need to improve their English proficiency.

As globalisation and the ever increasing international competition advance new demands on the competences of our students and their knowledge og international affairs, the consortium has in recent years enhanced its focus on international activities and international programs. By offering our students the opportunity of studying abroad, we assist them in their preparation for the future labour market, thus enhancing their international career possibilities. In our experience, students who have spent time studying abroad meet the requirements of the international labour market in terms of flexibility, independence, and their will to embark on new challenges at home as well as in another culture. 

The consortium wishes to offer our students the possibility of acquiring international competences in the UK and Hungary. Generally, students going through Vocational Education and Training do not have the same tradition or financial possibilities for going abroad to study, and the Erasmus + program is a unique chance for this group of students to get a head-start academically, personally and linguistically and thereby improving their possibilities of achieving relevant apprenticeship contracts and eventually gain footing on the labour market. 

The application and approval procedure of the consortium is extensive. Firstly, students and their parents are invited to a meeting where the different destinations are presented. Secondly, the students write a motivated application which is related to the student’s academic as well as personal competences, Thirdly, the approved candidates are invited for an interview where the student’s English proficiency is tested just as the personality is assessed. On the basis of the assessment, test, and interview, a forum consisting of the principal, teachers participating in the program and an international coordinators decide if the student can be approved for a study trip to one of the European destinations.

The trip is organised in cooperation with the hosting partners we have worked with for a number of years and who have specialised in cooperating with European VET schools and who enjoy a large network within the local business community and subsequently access to a wide range of work placements within the field of great relevance to our students. 

The students participate in a one-month program which includes college as well as work placement. The program starts with a college course where the students are introduced to the language and dos and don’ts, history and cultural understanding. After the course, the students continue in their work placements.  

Expectations:
On the basis of several years of experience, the consortium expects the students to return with more knowledge, more skills and new competences such as improved English proficiency, insight in another culture, new personal competences in terms of independence, determination and focus on their future career possibilities. Many of our students also develop the courage to apply for work placement abroad for part of their apprenticeship period.  

Furthermore, the consortium expects to develop new international contacts and networks.

Overview 
1. Activities and developments
2. Need for accompanying persons
3. Implementation of Internationalisation Strategy 

Activities and developments
This project involves two types of activities (learners and staff mobility), which both aim to strengthen the international competencies among staff and learners. The activities are to a great extent either a continuation of former or current projects and this is with a view to give a chance for more colleagues to benefit from the first moves that the staff mobilities created for us in previous one year plus. At the same time, we are requesting two additions, which happen on a background of 1) already knowing the partners very well from a KA2 and Interreg collaboration and wishing to consolidate results by staff learning exchanges. And 2) to step-up the support for our students to make shorter stays to explore possible new opportunities for finding traineeships with companies across the German Border. 

Plans of mobilities as per description in the Charter application:
First year (2016) Learners planned: 35 - realised: 37
First year (2016) Staff planned: 20 -realised:  18 (1)
Second year (2017) Learners planned:  20 (2) 
Second year (2017) Staff planned: 11 and 2018: 16 (3)

1) The 18 staff mobilities include accompanying teachers. Remaining will take place during in 2017. It is worth remarking that the first administrative staff will be among these.
2) For learners, the mobility programme for 2017 will contain that of Tietgen Business only. The turn has come to the gymnasium to have a new reform to fall into place and it has not been possible to involve a mobility trip in this year´s study schedule. It is expected that new learners´ mobility trip can be tested and approved for autumn of 2018.
3) We continue to follow a more restrictive number till staff have had a chance to be more familiar with the new reforms.

We recently shared this with our existing partners, and we received a very positive feedback; 
“At Tietgen we are very pleased and thankful for the spirit in which the collaboration around the exchanges has taken place. 
Partnerships for collaboration in education (PACE)
This will be the heading of our 2017 application and in which we are stating that our aim is to continue and consolidate the results Tietgen has experienced, in particular:
- Staff members returning with a lot of excitement “in their luggage”. They have been transferring this into a highly motivated and focused approach of including concrete international case material or advocating for getting a first hand international experience to their colleagues and students.
- Tietgen is keen to further develop such effects and shall be seeking to make our motilities go closely hand in hand with the needs and objectives for the various study programmes e.g.:
o Students’ search for internship/international practical training and trainee/apprentice  contracts;
o Teachers’ search for best practices in learning styles, learning facilitation, guidance activities etc.
o Staff’ search for broader understanding of practices around systems in education across countries incl. solutions to the ever-chancing profiles of special needs.
o As digitalization impact every field of business, our specific business related educational aims and practises cannot be excluded from this development. Knowledge and inspiration to/from the international community is vital for us also in this field.”

Need for accompanying persons for student groups during their stay overseas. 
The goal of the project in collaboration with London is that the students gain competencies of languages, cultural understanding majorly. Each student is required to prepare him or herself thoroughly and make a motivational application including their personal objectives with their education and traineeship. In addition, common objectives have been set for the exercise towards “increasing independence and self-confidence”. To these achievements, goes organising own meals, logistics etc.  What is then left as the teacher’s role and responsibility as accompanying teacher is on the one side practicalities in case of mishaps or emergencies. On the other side, it is to act as a mentor in support of the students’ recognising their own achievements and grow in self-confidence from it. The mentor support concludes in London during the evaluation session at the last days of their stay. The evaluation session is attended by IL London’s and Tietgen’s representatives and the student. The students receive a quality copy of their Europass Mobilty after this session. 
Implementation of our internationalisation strategy
The fact that learner mobilities are now supported and to be tested on-line for their language skills is a good match to Tietgen’s Internalisation Strategy. Language skills as part of the preparations for a stay, marks a quality assurance. Language check has been practiced at Tietgen and we look forward to embrace the digital elements.
Mobility and work-based learning, Business College Copenhagen North, 2015-2017

Mobility stays for Upper Secondary School Students:
The participants will be 3rd-year students of the 3-year Higher Commercial Examination Exam.  
The students will be taught topics relevant for their curriculum such as - British politics, economics, immigration, cultural awareness, labour market relations and the EU. Moreover, there will be grammar lessons and vocabulary training for their work placement. All teachers are native speakers.

The students will be accommodated in homestays which will strengthen the students’ language skills, communication and inter-cultural skills.
Through their work placement, they will acquire commercial understanding and knowledge about British companies. Types of jobs are e.g. office work, receptionist at a hotel, shop assistant.

An important objective of Business College Copenhagen North is to strengthen the international dimension in the education and to enhance our students’ ability to operate in an international work environment.  

Through this project, the students’ tolerance towards other cultures will be increased. Furthermore, their increased skills in the above areas will help the students in their future, further education.

The stays will take place in two 3-week flows, October/November 2016 and October/November 2017.
The students will study, work and stay in London or Brighton for 3 weeks. In London, a 1-week language course and a 2-week work placement. When they go to school, compulsory cultural tours will be planned during the afternoons.  In Brighton, a 3-week work placement with language classes on some evenings and 1 weekend. There will also be compulsory cultural tours during the weekend.

Mobility stays for students from the EUD programme in the field of commerce, retail and administration:
The goal of this project is to send students to Gower College Swansea, Wales, UK, to München, Germany and to London, UK during the schools year 2015-2016 and 2016-17. 
All mobility stays include language school for one or two weeks and training placement in companies (retail, commerce and administration) for one or two weeks. All stays are three-week stays.
The mobility project we have with Wales is based on student exchanges. First, the Welsh students come to Denmark to participate in classes at Business College Copenhagen North for one week and to have a two- week work practice. Half a year later the Danish students go to Gower College Swansea to follow a similar programme.

The purpose is to improve our students' competences in languages and internationalization, as these competences are part of KNORD's curriculum and therefore necessary to have in order to get the diploma. Moreover, this is a demand of all Danish vocational schools from The Danish Ministry of Education.
The purpose in general is to strengthen internationalisation in the vocational education that we offer at Business College Copenhagen North and to inspire our students to become more international, and experienced in the ways of the world. Additionally, the purpose is to improve their English and German language skills, as these are the languages we offer at our college. The students will be able to improve their competences in intercultural communication, and gain work experience from another country.  

The enhanced focus on internationalization at our college will prepare the students for the future job market and strengthen their competitiveness when applying for a traineeship.

This project will add an extra European dimension to the EUD programme at our vocational business college.
Strenghtening international competencies among staff and learners

This project involves two types of activities (learners and staff mobility), which both aim to strengthen the international competencies among staff and learners. The activities are to a great extent either a continuation of former or current projects or significantly inspired by those. 1) Learners mobility activities:Tietgen Business (HG2-students)Our former Tietgen HG (now Tietgen Business) has been arranging mobility projects with great success for 8 years. Anne Melbourne has been our contact in the UK for all these years. The cooperation has been excellent which is why we wish to continue the project. The project will consist of 20 HG2 students and take place in Spring, 2017. The students will be carefully chosen from different classes. The programme last for 4 weeks of which 3 weeks will be with accompanying teachers. These teachers will stay with the students for one week each.  Tietgen Handelsgymnasium (HHX-students)Inspired by extremely successful student mobility projects at our former Tietgen HG (now Tietgen Business), we wish to initiate as similar possibility in our HHX-department. The project will involve all our 3rd year students enrolled in our program ‘Culture and Language (with Spanish)’. This study programme includes Spanish A, Marketing A and Culture B. They have been learning Spanish for a bit over 2 years when they leave for Spain on their 3rd year. Therefore, they should have a basic understanding of the language they are going to be communication in for three weeks. The fact that Culture B is also a part of the programme is a big advantage as the students also have learned a lot about cultural differences and have a good theoretical cultural understanding. And this project will make them experience the Spanish culture and hopefully contribute to gaining a hands-on experience with cultural differences. The three week stay will consist of a one week long work placement in a local business. The local businesses will be selected by our local partner Debla in Malaga. The first two weeks of the stay will be a mix of language classes and activities involving using the Spanish language and learning about Spanish culture, the way of doing business and other relevant topics. As we wish to send 38 students from two different classes, there will be a bit of difference regarding their Spanish level. Therefore, the language teaching will take this into account as the students will be divided into groups according to level. When selecting work placements for the students, the abilities of each student will also be considered to ensure that the students do their internship in a firm where the language skills required match their skills. The students will be accompanied by teachers. Two teacher will travel with the students to Malaga and be replaced by two other teachers half way through the programme, who will travel with the students back to Denmark. 2) Staff mobility activities:In line with our current KA1 project (DAICOT) we wish to continue developing our network of partner schools with which we can arrange staff exchanges. We have chosen to bring in two partners schools that we have known for a while and collaborated on other projects/activities, but which are both new partners to us in the KA1 context. These partners are carefully selected from among a number of interesting and interested partners, which all had some relevant input to contribute with. Our two new KA1 partners we selected because of our good knowledge of the institutions, which have both been visited by Tietgen staff at previous occasions (on exchanges, study trips, project meetings etc.) and because the two institutions have very much in common with Tietgen in many ways (e.g. the subjects taught). As our current KA1 project is still running till May 2017, we are only applying for a few extra staff exchanges in this application in order to make sure that we do not ask for more than we expect to use. We have made clear agreements with all partners. In order to demonstrate how the tasks are divided among partners, we have attached a MoU of one of the staff mobility partnerships and one of the learners mobility partnerships. The details varies a bit, but it should give an idea of how we work. We have also attached a document with comments regarding the feedback we got on our charter application.

Aarhus Business Colleges (AABC) launches a new strategic initiative; a talent programme, EUX Business International, starting august 2017.
The goal of the new programme is to attract a new type of student who has the ability to complete a more academic type of upper secondary education, but who is interested in gaining other skills and who is attracted by the international aspect of this particular programme.  

Students at this programme will be taught English and Danish at A level, Current Affairs, Marketing and Mathematics at B level and some topics will be executed in English. The contents of the programme is currently being developed, but all topics will have an international approach, and the companies which students will be working with and visiting during the programme will all have English as their corporate language.

Students who are admitted to this programme are committed to participate in two study trips:
1. a three week Erasmus+ study and training trip to London during the first term, and 
2. a four week study trip to an overseas destination during the third term. 
Therefore, AABC applies for 30 mobilities for the academic year 2017-2018 and another 30 for the academic year 2018-2019, i.e., a total of 60 mobilities. EUX Business International will be developed in cooperation with Intuition London (IL), a partner AABC has cooperated with for a great many years and who knows the vocational education and training programme very well, is familiar with the type of student at AABC, just as IL knows the staff at AABC who have enjoyed a close cooperation with the managing director at IL, Anne Melbourne, over the years.

Before the most recent reforms within vocational education and training, AABC offered carefully selected students the opportunity to attend a combined training and study trip to London during their third term. Due to new requirements in terms of curriculum, AABC and IL had to develop a new programme, which did not leave room for training as an intense focus on the academic goals was required. 

As a consequence and based on AABC’s Strategy 2020 and the European 2020 strategy, we wish to resuscitate the former programme with the amendments and adjustments required as we are dealing with students at their first term and students who are extremely young.

The students will be:
• spending half the time in London training, and 
• the other half in college learning English and Marketing. 

The purpose of the study and training trip is:
• to make students realise the value of looking for an apprenticeship immediately after the first two years of college and thereby finish the education before moving on to further education,
• to inform students about and encourage them to look for apprenticeships abroad immediately after the first two years of college. 

Unlike former students, this group will not have been submitted to a long recruitment and screening procedure; they are going because they chose this particular programme. Furthermore, the students are young (15-16 years). Therefore, AABC has an important task convincing the students and their parents that students will be looked after 24/7. 

Hence, accompanying staff will be at the students disposal at all times, and during the three weeks, students will be accompanied by two members of staff.  This is a unique opportunity for students and staff to get to know each other early in the programme and in a context outside college. 

Therefore, we apply for three accompanying staff mobilities, each will be staying one week, and another three staff mobilities who will participate in one-week courses to develop their competences, but who will also assist their colleague in the evenings and weekends planning cultural activities. 

The accompanying staff will participate in all lessons at college and visit students when training in companies.  This will develop their oral proficiency and develop their intercultural competences, which they can implement in their lessons when returning to Denmark and thereby contribute to the international perspective of the programme. 
Staff participating in training courses will focus on:
• English,
• International trade,
• International economics.

AABC goals in terms of developing staff are ambitious. Academic as well as educational, but just as important is the fact that topics can be placed in a practical and global context. Thus, the goal for staff competence development during the programme is to develop their English proficiency, academic skills and last, but not least their intercultural understanding. 
Choice of courses depends on which may be available during the weeks 45, 46, and 47.

Our project is called "Minute & Artistic Metalworking”, or MAM-project.  

Thanks to this project, 41 final-year students studying clock-making or jewellery would go abroad for a two-week training.

The schools or training centres would provide a specific training linked to minute and precise metal working techniques.

The clock-making students would go to the AFPA centre in Besançon to follow a training on finishing : they will learn how to  verify the cleanliness and freedom of mobile of the exhaust, then to ensure mechanical functions up limiting losses of the energy transmitted to the regulating body. Then, they will learn more about the movements, the faces and the hands and how to deal with a waterproof problem.

The jewellers will learn various techniques with our partners in France, Spain, Portugal and the UK. These techniques include lost wax, enamelling , filigree and CAD. In each of these training, the students will learn more about the specificities linked to working the metal, the techniques used in order to transform it into a jewel and they will also learn how to manage the material, products and tools.

We also wish to enrich our students culturally and to help them discover another part of Europe. They will learn about the architecture, the history, and the traditions in this part of Europe. We are certain that the contacts they will make with the people from there will be enriching and mind-opening.

The trip will take place in spring 2019. It will be prepared, both by the teachers in our school, IATA, and the people responsible for their training either at AFPA or in the diverse jewellery schools. The students will be assessed by the partners and the knowledge and skills they acquire there will be highlighted and acknowledged through their marks in their school reports.

When they come back, not only will they have learned new techniques, but they will also have changed their vision of Europe and of their European identity. They will also know more about the importance of acquiring skills through training and professional life. We are confident that this stay will also provide them with new experience in relationships, teaching them about how to behave in society and boosting their self-esteem.

Thanks to all this, the students will have more strings to their bow which shall enable them to be more competitive on the job market, since they will be more qualified and will prove international experience. For the school and the horology section, this trip also provides cohesion among the teachers making up the team and will boost them in continuous training.

Získavajme praktické odborné zručnosti v zahraničí

Obchodná akadémia Poprad is a secondary vocational school with a long history as an educational institution providing secondary education in the field of business studies. There are two fields of studies at our school at the present time, the business administration and administration in tourism. The graduates of the school are interested in finding a job in the administration of different businesses and state organisations and in the organisations involved in tourism. The projects picks up on the preceding project from the 2017 Call "We want to know and learn more". It is designed for the students of the third and fourth year of both study fields and enables them to take part in VET learners internships in the companies abroad in London in cooperation with ADC College London. Each trainee takes part in two week internship while performing the activities according their field of study and  gain practical, professional skills and competences. Altogether 13 students - 10 students of the field business administration and 3 students of the field administration in tourism with two accompanying teachers wil take part in the internship. The aim of the project is to strengthen the connection between theoretical and practical  learning, gain practical work experience, compare work environment and conditions in the companies in Slovakia and the UK, increase their language skills, learn about other cultures and increase their chance to find a proper job after finishing their secondary studies.  The aim is also to motivate not only the participants in the project but also other students to continue their studies in this field, to study English and to attract the future students to study at our school.  The most important outcome of the project are the professional skills and competences recorded in Europass Mobility document and will serve to prove the students´skills and competences while looking for the job in Slovakia and abroad in EU countries. Another outcome is that the students receive internationally acknowledged learning outcomes - ECVET documents. The students will also improve their communication skills using everyday and business English. The long-term goal is to increase the change of our students to find a job in European job market. The school also wants to foster its European dimension by performing this project.
Strategic Partnerships Supporting Exchange of Good Practices in Teaching in Jewellery Manufacturing and Design Across Europe

Holts Academy of Jewellery (UK), Trier University of Applied Sciences (Germany) and Alchimia Contemporary Jewellery School (Italy), recognize the need to ensure that programme content remains as relevant as possible and responds to the changing needs of the industry and consumers, so as to produce practitioners that are able to successfully compete as well as drive the growth and success of the industry at national, regional and international levels. Keen to build connections across Europe, all partners see the value of sharing practices unique to each institution as well regionally, as a means of strengthening provision for learners across VET and Higher Education institutions and ensuring that each partner remains at the forefront of teaching in jewellery creation and design.The project would involve the exchange of 4 tutors between London, Berlin and Italy, who would undertake teaching placements for a minimum of 2 months. During their placements, all tutors will engage in the sharing of making and design skills and methods through the delivery of projects, master classes, the shadowing of lessons, lectures and seminars, and upon their return, expected to  feed back to their institutions with regards to the possible enhancement of existing programmes, as well as share their newfound skills and experiences with fellow tutors and learners.At the end of the project, three exhibitions would be held in London, Idar-Oberstein and Florence respectively, which would be an opportunity to showcase the outcomes of the project to fellow peers as well as the external public, including jewellery pieces produced by learners throughout. Holts Academy of Jewellery will also lead the creation and production of a joint publication, which will seek to discuss the experience of tutors and learners abroad, their views with regards to regional trends, the changing demands and required responsiveness of jewellery training institutions by way of programmes/curricula, as well as showcase the pieces produced throughout the project by the participants under instruction by the visiting tutors.

The project arises in a context of crisis and unemployment especially high among young people. Many of them, although they have completed their vocational educational studies and they are able to perform a job, don't have enough foreign language skills, or other professional and personal skills that make them less competitive in a labor market increasingly demanding.



The project's main objective is to promote personal and professional development of these student-workers and their specific skills through exchanges and internships, to acquire specific knowledge and skills in their professional sector to facilitate their access to labour market and prepare them for an economic context more and more globalized.



It is expected the participation of 23 young people who will practice in the professional field of Business Administration, Tourism, Hotels, Cooking, Health, Electricity, Telecommunications and Automotive.in companies in Germany (BBZ), Portugal (Equity Point and Braga MOB), Italy (CIOFS FP Association and ENFE), Denmark (Padel Denmark), Czech Republic (Equity Point) and United Kingdom (Spanish Connection and Ibérica London), for three months along 2014, 2015 and until June 2016. 



FULDEFE (Leonese Fundation for Economic Development, Training and Employment) is the coordinator partner of the project and the sending organisation together with IES Ordoño II, María Auxiliadora High School, Don Bosco High School, and IES Giner de los Ríos.



FULDEFE has a long experience in managing European projects with a transnational dimension, five of them Mobility Projects, four of them under Leonardo da Vinci program. FULDEFE teaches FOD workshops and DUAL programs since its inception. FULDEFE obtained in 2013 quality accreditation (ISO 9001) and environment accreditation (ISO 14001). Projects Office of FULDEFE will be in charge of the management of the project, with the transversal support of administration and training and employment departments.

The Business Academy, Topolcany (OA TO) is a secondary vocational school founded in 1968. It has long-term experience in the field of education and training of students for execution of economic activities. Besides gaining theoretical knowledge in vocational subjects such as Economics, Accountancy, Administration and Correspondence, IT and foreign language learning supported by the subject Business English, students have the chance to apply their knowledge and skills in the subject Training Firm and during their work experience in the real work environment. 
OA TO as the applicant organisation  will organize the students´ mobility in sept-oct 2017 in cooperation with the intermediary and partner organisation ADC College based in London and other partner organisations.  
All aims of the project „From Theory to Practice“ are in accordance with European priorities in a national context and operational aims of Erasmus+ programme in Slovakia for 2017.
The main aim of the project is to improve students´ knowledge, skills and competences in the field of Administration and Correspondence and Business English and via acquired experience improve their employability and chance to get a better place in the labour market in Slovakia and Europe.
The specific aim of the project is to improve the quality of vocational education and training at OA TO, to link theory with practice and support work-based learning by a month work experience in London companies as the result of partnerships between OA TO and the companies in London.
The participants get invaluable experience while having an internship in work, culture and language environment of London companies and staying in a European city and thus gain a better sense of self-realization, initiative and business, build their confidence and self-reliance, get a new perspective on the world of work, develop their cultural awareness and improve their language skills using English language in real-life situations.
The project of the work experience in London is also a motivation tool for current and potential students of OA TO to improve their academic results and language skills as they are part of the selection criteria and essential  preconditions for doing well throughout its duration. 
Number and profile of the participants:
20 students of the 4th grade of OA TO (6317M field of study-Business Academy)
2 accompanying persons (teachers of OA TO)
Description of activities:
Tasks of OA TO:
Selecting the students according to the selection criteria.
Working out all the relevant documents and contracts.
Administrating Online Linguistic Support and entry/exit tests within Erasmus+ programme, providing Business English Language Training and Culture Clash lectures.
Holding an informative meeting for the participants and their parents.
Gathering questio nformation about the participants.
Transport to and from London.
Ensuring the students´ protection and security, monitoring in families and companies.
Evaluating the learning outcomes and disseminating the project.
Tasks of Partner/Host organisations:
Fostering understanding of the culture and mentality of the host country
Assigning to participants tasks and responsibilities to match their knowledge, skills and competences and training objectives set out in the Learning Agreement and ensuring appropriate equipment and support. 
Identifying a mentor to monitor and evaluate the participant's training progress.
Providing support if required for trainees that face difficulties. 
Tasks of ADC College:
Providing contact details of all parties involved and ensuring that final arrangements are in place prior to participants' departure.
Selecting host organisations in the field of Business and Correspondence that are able to achieve the internship objectives and placing the students in them.
Arranging the accommodation and board in host families, and public transport in London.
Holding an induction seminar for the participants on the day of arrival.
Agreeing mentoring and monitoring of the students.
Methodology:
Questionnaires, interview,  observing, records, report on the mobility
Estimated results and impact and potential long-term benefits:
Achieving all the project´s aims the students  will develop their professional knowledge, skills, competences in the intented field,  gain a better sense of self-realization, initiative and business, become more confident and self-reliant, develop their cultural awareness and improve their language skills, which will help them get employed and get a better place in the labour market in Slovakia and Europe.
The project will improve the quality of vocational education and training at OA TO, support work-based learning and partnerships between the school and companies, strenghten the modernization and internationalization of the school and enhance its good reputation. It will also arouse interest in studying at OATO as school which trains quality and qualified graduates with language skills.

The Secondary School of Business in Vranov nad Topľou is a secondary vocational school specialized in vocational education and training in the field of economics, which is based on the study of economic subjects, relevant legislation, ICT and languages (Slovak, English, German, Russian). Most of our pupils are interested in English. The school provides education in a four-year study programme. The added value of studying at our school is emphasizing the necessity of linking theory to practice through training companies in which students can practically verify their knowledge and skills in a simulated foreign business environment. Furthermore, pupils in the 3rd and 4th grade must complete compulsory vocational practice at the agreed workplaces. This is where we are opening the door to identifying our need to deepen the linking of theory to practice, so that we produce not only theoretical experts for the labour market but especially experienced and practically trained experts with active communication in the English language. In 2017, for the first time in the history of the school, we were able to implement compulsory vocational experience in companies abroad through Erasmus +, KA1 Mobility of VET Learners and Staff. This activity was a great success not only among the 15 pupils who attended it, but also among other pupils and teachers. Moreover, the school has also been successful distinguishing itself from other schools, making it more attractive. Therefore, we decided to continue this activity by submitting another application under this program. The importance of vocational practice in the international environment is mainly seen in improving the starting position of future graduates of the secondary school of business in the national and European labour market.
The aim of this project is to increase the employability of our pupils in the labour market through the realization of foreign vocational mobility which will increase the professional skills and competencies of the pupils. The subject of the project is the realization of foreign mobilities, which will take place in the Czech Republic (specifically in Ostrava) and in England (specifically in London) for a duration of 2 weeks - 10 working days, 14 days together with a journey and a weekend.  It will be attended by 26 pupils together. Through our collaboration with the ADC College in England, 12 of our pupils will be located in companies operating in the Business administration area. As part of mobility in the Czech Republic, pupils will be placed in the following companies: Account Professional, Wincott People, Yakovidis - Klega Partners. The project´s realization will be supervised by the project team composed of – a project manager, project coordinator, financial manager, to ensure its quality. By completing foreign mobilities, pupils will get an overview of the functioning of the labour market in England and the Czech Republic, entrepreneurship opportunities, rights and obligations of entrepreneurs, principles of the real estate business, information about career growth opportunities and youth employment promotion, social policy and the social system in England, the functioning and operating conditions, as well as of the charitable organization financing system, a brief overview of the subsidy policy, learn about English language teaching methods, about the importance of marketing whether in personal life or in a working business environment. The greatest benefit of the project at the pupils' personal level will be the acquisition of new experience and professional skills, including the improvement of language competencies. The project will provide them with a unique life experience and will motivate them to further professional, linguistic and personal growth. They will learn how it works in a foreign company, they will get acquainted with the duty to go to work, to have a fixed working time, to work in a multi-ethnic group, to be responsible and to realize the importance of work they have to do. The realization of the project also benefits school. The importance of vocational practice in the international environment is mainly reflected in the improvement of the starting position of future graduates of the business school in the national and European labour market. The London internship increased, according to the response of the Day of Open Door in December 2017, the attractiveness of vocational training and the interest in getting high-quality vocational and communication competencies at our school. Last but not least, the image of school has improved, as well as the motivation of pupils from lower grades to acquire vocational and linlinguistic competencies in order to take part in a similar internship. We are convinced that the implementation of this project and its further repetition will clearly increase the chances of our pupils to succeed in the labour market while also attracting other potential candidates to study at our school.

The applicant of project is The Secondary School of Business in Vranov nad Topľou, one of the most successful and most famous educational institutions in the field of vocational training in the region. Currently, 228 students attend the school. The four-year study programme provides education in economics, such as accounting, business administration and applied informatics. It also provides training in foreign languages (English, German and Russian). Most of our students are interested in the English language. The added value of studying at our school is emphasis on the necessity of connecting theory with practice through training companies in which students have the opportunity to test their knowledge and skills practically in a simulated foreign business environment. 
Furthermore, students in grades 3 and 4 must undergo mandatory vocational practice in agreed workplaces. Here opens up space for our identification of the need to deepen linking theory with practice so that we produce not only theoretical professionals for the labor market, but especially experienced and highly flexible professionals with active communication in English.
Therefore, we defined the project objective: To increase the applicability of our students in the labor market through the implementation of foreign professional mobility by the improvement of professional and language competences of pupils.
The situation regarding employment after graduation is steadily worse, and finding a job is a difficult process, so we decided to respond to the situation and increase the chances of our students for employment by supplementing our educational process of implementation of international mobility, the content of which would be passing job training in foreign companies.
It concerns the implementation of foreign mobility, which will take place in England, in London, for a period of two weeks, 10 working days, 14 days along with the journey and weekends and involves a total of 15 students from the 4th grades of school. They will be accompanied by two English language teachers, active in our school. The selection of these 15 students will take place according to the results of professional language tests.
Through cooperation with the educational institution ADC College, which in this project plays the role of facilitator, our students, based on test results, will be placed in companies operating in Business Administration - Companies of ADC College, AS Accountancy, Adolphus Group, Age UK Westminster, Avalon School, Big Choice Group, Century 21 Chiswick, Central School of English. All listed companies are in a contractual relationship with ADC College and respect the evaluation within ECVET.
 To ensure the quality of the project, its implementation will take place under the supervision of the project team composed of a project manager, a project coordinator and a financial manager.
Taking part in foreign mobility, students will gain insight into the functioning of the labor market in England, business opportunities, rights and obligations of economic operators, the principles of operation of the real estate business, they will get information about career opportunities and support of young people in employment, about social policy and social system in England, about the operation and its conditions as well as the system of financing charities, brief overview of the subsidy policies, they will acquire information about the methods of teaching English language, the importance of marketing, whether in personal life or in the working business environment.
The impact of the project on participants:
Increase and improvement of key competences of students:
- learn to evaluate their own work independently, find reserves,
- learn to convert weaknesses to strengths and threats into opportunities.
Increase and improvement of professional competences:
- obtain an overall view on the issue of the private sector market functioning
- obtain information about the social system in England and its use by socially disadvantaged citizens
- obtain information about the operation of the third sector in the marketplace - (nonprofits, charities)
- acquisition and improvement of technical skills (ICT skills, working with feeds, databases)
- improve communication skills in English
Contribution of the project: to increase the quality of vocational education and training students for the labor market to withstand the competitive environment and to demonstrate the knowledge and experience which other applicants miss, possibly to show their greater sense of initiative and entrepreneurship, which would be supported by the experience acquired in the foreign market. We see the possibility that students will establish contacts and informal partnerships with foreign companies, where they have performed their practice and those will provide advice and consultation to start their own business, or help in finding a job.

The project is a workshop with thirty participants comming from 5 countries and different artistic backgrounds. It will be held in a place made for residency next to Lyon in Haute-Loire. It can be defined by three main axes.



First of all the "collaborative experience": The main goal of the workshop is to share our experiences of filmmaking as a collaborative research and decision process, where everyone's word is listened and considered in a positive way. Opening new horizons for audiovisual creation, we decided to mix a large panel of arts and skills. Eventhough, the audiovisual creation is the central object of the project, it must be intended in a much broader meaning: the technical quality of the film made by participants aren’t as important as the experience itself. Filmmaking becomes a mutual responsibility, emulating connexions between people, connexions between ideas, and as such a great tool for collective experience.



Creation is thus the final product of the workshop. Since the participants come with a great panel of different backgrounds, the staff will leave the maximum total freedom about the content of the works. We expect that each artists will infuse the final result with his/her own personnality and desires. 



Finally, the project is about sharing. Sharing the same space and the same process, despite our the cultural differences, we will be trussed in a common involvement of respecting some human values and endeavouring to understand eachother needs, in terms of both aspects: living and creating.



The project can see with three times : 



- In the first time, we'll present the programme, the aims of the workshop and develop a collective dynamic. There will time for the presentations of the associations, the countries, the participants and their artistic fields. A collaborative experience is at first a human incounter, and the expression of a commun interest and desire.  Our Project is build on this idea, thus we will leave the proper time for the youth workers to get to know themselves and think of the type of collaborative experience they wil leave.



 - In the a second time, participants will have the times to bring their own theorical and pratical contributions about audiovisual creation. As a preparation, we ask them to write a short presentation about their activity as youth workers and artistic work. It's an efficient way to know each other and rich personal experience.During the first three days, we'll have short trainings with camera, sound gears, editing system, and the tools and competences we'll have with them. We won't provide a full technical training and to bring up the issues oaf audiovisual creation and its encounter with other arts and practices, as well as its great potential as a tool for youth workers. The game of the reel is a good example : spreading a wool reed between the participants as they speak and discuss about their activity and the projects they will build together.



- The third part of the workshop will be the making of the audiovisual creations. We plan a time for the presentation of the main themes of Erasmus +. We'll leave some to the participants to think about it and then have a discussion about them and how to work with it through the audiovisual projects. Groups will be freely made, with a staff referent for each one. The main idea is to get the participants responsible, and leave the confront with issues of collaboratives experience, although we'll provide a methodological and technical support. It will brings out a real diversity of creations, in terms of meanings and forms. We will also organize a public presentation of the works for the inhabitants of the village nearby, screen the creations with our traveling theater or put in the public space the installations and works made by the participants. This last part intent to give the participants the opportunity to work on the whole process of collaborative creation, from writing, to making to public presentation.

European and international youth organizations play an important role in responding to the challenge of the increasing racism and intolerance towards refugees, migrants and people of color and the rising nationalism and radicalisation of youth which over the past 2 years has become more and more threatening to peace and democracy in many countries of the EU and in other countries worldwide. In an immigration society youth organisations ought to be facilitators of inclusion. As such they need to be credible institutions who base their anti-racist work on a truly anti-racist structure, an anti-racist culture and an anti-racist understanding of all members of the NGO. 

In this context the aim of  this partnership project is to strengthen the role and profile of  youth NGO's in combating racism and facilitating dialogue and inclusion while also adapting their structures to become more accessible and sensitive to the needs and situation of migrants, refugees and PoCs.  Both the administrative and educational staff and co-workers of youth NGOs will be involved in the project. They will share experiences and put together their strengths in changing their organizations into truly anti-racist organizations AND in developing innovative concepts and strategies for empowering young people of color, refugees and migrants by involving them in international youth work activities. 

The partnership is composed of 7 youth NGOs from Germany, Denmark, Finland, France, Iceland, Slovakia and UK working at national and international level. It also includes a Hungarian organisation specialized in and working at European level on anti-racism training and a a nonprofit consultancy with working experience in the civil society sector in Germany and internationally for more than 18 years. 

The main innovative element is that the project activities inter-relate the field of anti-racism training and the concept of anti-racism oriented change management of youth NGOs. The main project  activities consist in 6 transnational meetings which will take place in 6 different programme countries from September 2017 to March 2020.  Besides planning the project implementation these meetings will include thematic workshops. 3 workshops will enable youth workers trainers and multipliers to reflect about their own role and way of working, gain method knowledge in anti-racism youth work as well as develop innovative methods and youth activities in this field. Another 3 workshops will allow staff, decision makers and coworkers of  youth NGOs to reflect about tools and methods which can make their organisation more sensitive to racism, more inclusive and more active in combatting racism, nationalism and radicalization of young people.  

As underpinning learning measures the partnership will simultaneously implement two Key Action 1 projects. One will focus on the training of youth workers in anti-racism training and one will focus on providing administrative and decision-making staff and stakeholders of youth NGOs to learn about change management. 

To sustain the results of the project and to enhance the visibility of this project,  two intellectual outputs will be generated, one on change management tools and methods and one on anti-racism training methods in the context of anti-racism. The results of the project will be promoted in 9 multiplying events which will be organized by the partners in each of the participating countries. 

The partnership expects that the project will inspire other European youth NGO's to take similar steps and to make use of the strategies, methods and tools generated, adapting them to their own organizational and societal context. The project will thus contribute to the quality of youth work in Europe and hopefully also to overcoming racism in European Societies.
Skills and Competences for a Global World

Economic instability and competitiveness on labour markets make the focus on skills and competences of young people crucial to their holistic development and employability. In times when right-wing populism is on the rise, youth and voluntary work is key to changing mindsets and reminding people that solidarity is the answer to our problems, not division; to promoting common European values, fostering social integration and intercultural understanding. The project thus aims to strengthen and assess the impacts of intercultural learning in terms of skills and competences young people gain during their voluntary service.Aims1) To professionalise IVS organisations and trainers to reach their goals in fostering intercultural learning, solidarity and the values of human rights, and setting up an international pool of ICL trainers.2) To boost skills and competences of young people and their ability to participate actively in society, and to enhance social cohesion, solidarity and inclusion within local communities across 4 world regions. 3) To test the impacts of the intercultural learning process on volunteers’ skills and competences, and to examine the needs and strengths of IVS organisations in volunteer management, training and support.Activities-Taskforce Preparation Meeting-International Training for Trainers in ICL and qualitative research-EVS for 13 volunteers-ICL trainings for EVS volunteers & other local and international volunteers in 12 countries: Austria, Finland, Poland, Slovakia, UK, Brazil, Colombia, Honduras, India, Indonesia, Kenya and Nigeria-Impact study testing volunteers’ skills and competences in the 12 countries-Taskforce Final Evaluation MeetingTangible outcomes1) Professionalization of trainers in ICL and creation of a pool of trainers2) Organisations proficient in research, volunteer management, training and support 3) Greater understanding of strengths and weaknesses of each partner organisation and each region, and strengthened regional and international cooperation4) Products: a) An Activity Report of the Training for Trainers; b) New Practical Guide for ICL Trainings and new and adapted methods and theoretical input; c) Impact Study Report and new research methodology to assess skills and competencesImpact on stakeholders-Professional trainers with enhanced ICL and research skills and competences-Improved quality and practices of IVS organisations in volunteer management, training and support, serving the sustainable development of organisations and local communities-Strengthened cooperation among IVS organisations and local NGOs, and greater recognition of volunteering and work at grassroots level-Enhanced skills and competences and holistic development of young people and volunteers, improving employability options and ability to actively participate in society

This project has been developed on the basis of a strong existing partnership between the coordinating, sending and receiving organisations and following on from a number of successful EVS projects.
The project consists of two 11-month EVS activities involving a total of 8 participants, from 5 different countries and which will take place at two organisations in the UK, Treloar Trust and the Orpheus Centre. Treloar Trust and the Orpheus Centre both work to support young people with disabilities to fulfil their potential and to develop the skills needed to live as independent lives as possible.  The project includes partner organisations from Austria, Denmark, Germany, Italy and Slovakia. 
The project provides opportunities for personal development for the participants through a positive non-formal learning experience.  There are well defined expected learning outcomes for the participants that are matched to their personal interests, motivations and needs. Through the participants’ active role within the receiving organisations it is expected that this project will also be a positive learning experience for both the Orpheus Centre and Treloar Trust and in particular their students.  The organisations and their students are expected to benefit from the daily interaction, enthusiasm and motivation of the participants and in particular from the intercultural and European dimension that their presence will bring to the work of the organisations. This will be particular benefit to the students as they often have few opportunities to travel and experience other cultures.
It is expected that this project will also promote the positive aspects of cultural diversity within a team and at an organisational level as well as promoting the mutual benefits that can be attained through young people's active citizenship. In addition, it is expected that this project will support the work of the organisations in developing a greater awareness of disability; this will be reflected in the learning of the participants, the partner organisations and wider society.  
The project is expected to have a positive impact on the participants as through their active involvement they will gain tangible skills, knowledge and competences that will be of benefit to them in their future careers. The impact of the project will also be seen though the increased intercultural awareness of the students at the receiving organisations and also through the opportunity to share and develop best practice in the field of youth mobility between the organisations involved.
Young Activists for Peace and Dialogue

In view of an increase in religiously motivated discrimination and violence against society members who have a different religion or worldview in European Societies, the aim aof this project is to strengthen the foundations for peaceful communities by fostering peaceful dialogue between young people of the EU, Turkey and neighbouring partner countries.

The project's aim is to enable young people and youth workers within a holistic and peace-oriented pedagogical process to engage in peaceful dialogue and to stand up against anti-muslim tendencies and radicalisation of young people. A total of 88 young people and youth workers will be reached from 6 programme countries (Belgium, Germany, France, Greece, Turkey and UK) and from 5 neighboring partner countries (Azerbaijan, Georgia, Russia, Israel and Palestine). Their empowerment to active, responsible and openminded citizens will enable them to participate as active citizens in the fight against rightwing proganda, discrimination against muslims and human rights violations against refugees and migrants. In this way the project supports the Paris declaration of the EU education ministers (of 17.March 2015) fostering the common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination. The project  emphasises the importance of including young people in this struggle and process and to make their voice being heard. 

Within the  "Dialogue for Peace" context the project consists of 4 main activities which will be carried out in the year 2017: 1) 12 months of EVS placement for 2 volunteers from Greece and Germany in the offices of ICJA in Berlin and Frankfurt and their participation in this and similar projects of ICJA. 2) A Training seminar on the pedagocical concept "Young people as agents of peace" which will enable 26 participants from 11 countries to acquire methodological know-how and develop more sensitivity for the youth work  in the context of different religions and worldviews. 3) A youth exchange in the anti-war centre Sievershausen where 30 young people from 3 programm and 3 partner countries will be trained as "peace makers" and will participate in encounters and joint activitities with 30-40 young refugees living close by.  4) A second youth exchange will be held close to the city Wittenberge. The youth exchange  will once again train 30 young people as "peace makers" and enable them to meet with young people in the world exhibition which is dedicated to the 500 anniversary of the reformation in 2017. Here they will jointly explore the themes of the 7 "Gates of Freedom" and reflect upon them from their own background and point of view. In both youth exchanges 6 groups of 5 participants from 6 different countries (including refugees) will be involved. This intense experience of living, reflecting, learning, working and deciding together will be a good practive for democrativ decision-making and peaceful conflict resolution.  This will foster the capacity of participants to engage in dialogue and to have a better understanding of conflicts between religions and/or worldviews. This experience will also provide ideas on how to become active and how to participate in the construction of peaceful and pluralist societies in the EU and worldwide.
Volunteering for the Inclusion of Diverse Abilities

This project has been developed on the basis of a strong existing partnership between the coordinating and receiving organisations and following on from a number of successful projects involving these organisations.  The project aims to provide a positive non-formal learning experience for the 7 participants from 6 different European countries who will take part.  The project will consist of two 11-month EVS activities which will take place at two organisations, Treloar Trust and the Orpheus Centre in the UK.  The activities have been planned with clear learning objectives for the participants and with a strong focus on personal development and intercultural awareness. In the activities the participants will be actively involved in the day to day work of the organisations and their roles will focus on interaction with the students.  The participants will have the chance to develop their role according to their personal interest. They will be provided with the necessary training and support to achieve the planned learning outcomes.
