Calling Youth to Action in a Global Visibility Drive

YouACT aims to develop a visibility strategy to promote the value of volunteering and stimulate youth participation worldwide. This requires a communication strategy that is goal-driven, on-going, cost effective, well-timed and has clear targets. YouACT's partners will be able to modernize and internationalize their public relations and external communication systems, and likewise enhance skillsets of youth workers (i.e. staff, mentors, volunteers...). The wider the promotion, the greater the recognition of youth voluntary work and non-formal learning, the higher the numbers of youth stimulated to active participation, and the larger the impact on youth policies and systems in EU and partner countries. Aims: I. Visibility: Create global visibility by promoting volunteering in 21 countries on 4 continents and reaching large numbers of youth, incl. young people with fewer opportunities, to inspire them to active citizenship, and to forge new partnerships for youth and voluntary work.II. Building Capacity: Develop a tailor-made visibility strategy and enhance the non-formal education and communication skillset of youth workers.Activities: 1. Visibility Kick Off, Berlin, Germany 2. Calling Youth to Action: Multipliers’ Training for a Global Visibility Drive, Accra, Ghana3. Calling Youth to Action in promotion campaigns in 21 countries: Austria, Germany, Denmark, France, Finland, Iceland, UK, Poland, Slovakia, Switzerland, Bolivia, Brazil, Costa Rica, Colombia, Kenya, Ghana, Nigeria, Mozambique, India, Nepal and Vietnam4. Visibility Evaluation, Paris, FranceTangible Results: a) Global network of communication multipliers from 10 European, 4 Latin American, 4 African, and 3 Asian countries develop a visibility strategy and implement  it together with volunteers, youth, host projects...b) An international visibility training for 25 communication-multipliersc) Campaigns raising awareness of volunteering in 21 countries involving diverse stakeholders and reaching youth, NGOs and the wider publicd) A visibility strategy and visibility guide for ongoing, long-term, sustainable and result-oriented promotion and disseminatione) Strengthened existing partnerships, new collaborations with NGOs, local authorities/ministries, host projects, other youth/volunteering organisationsf) Active participation of increased number of youth in volunteering and civil society Impact on youth, volunteers, civil society, volunteering NGOs and local communities:a) Greater visibility, recognition and validation of volunteering and non-formal learning worldwideb) Long-term increase in global youth engagement in local communities in 21 countries c) Cultural exchange at local and international levels will fosters cultural diversity, equality and solidarity d) Strengthened partnerships and new collaborations and partnershipse) Hands-on campaigning work will foster youth entrepreneurship and employability, build leadership, creativity and responsibility

SEEDS organizes international volunteer workcamps with local communities, other associations and individuals all around Iceland. Jointly we develop projects aimed at fulfilling an identified need or to help in the development of particular actions. Projects are designed to be mutually beneficial to all involved: the individual volunteers, the local hosting communities and Iceland as a whole! 



In this project we will be involving 12 participants from European program countries with a keen motivation for working with international groups.



The EVS project will be divided in 4 parts, project training & language orientation (stage 1), preparation for the work in the field (2), field work (3) and evaluation & planning for next season (4). 



Volunteers will be in Reykjavík during stage 1 and 4; stages 2 and 3 will take place in different locations around Iceland. In this sense, volunteers will have the unique opportunity to experience Iceland in the capital but also to work and develop projects in different places all around the country.



The projects are often related to nature conservation, some examples include: removing invasive growth, building of walking paths or hiking trails, cleaning the coastline, reforestation and erosion control, construction or renovation of a building, heritage site or artwork. There are also some cultural, agricultural and study projects, as well as others which are based on identified needs of the local communities or associations. Groups’ sizes vary between 5 and 25 international participants.



There will be a division of the EVS volunteers in International Workcamp’s Leaders and Environmental messengers:



The volunteers selected for the International Workcamp’s Leaders project will be mainly in charge of leading the international workcamps at SEEDS, acting as a link between the Icelandic hosts and the International short term volunteers.  



The Environmental messengers role is to additionally raise awareness about environmental issues both within Icelanders, being hosts of SEEDS workcamps, and among the International volunteers taking part in the projects.  They will encourage the actors in those projects to undertake simple but easy-to-implement actions which will affect the way we use our resources and we deal with the environment and the world we live in.  Environmental messengers will get the opportunity to organize several environmental work camps during their stay. They will be responsible as a group for organizing activities, events and work that raise awareness in Iceland and amongst the volunteers about relevant environmental topics (e.g. recycling, waste management, water or air pollution, soil erosion, reforestation, fish stocks depletion, climate change, healthy living, eco-tourism, etc.). 



With this project we want to support local Icelandic initiatives that would not be possible without the involvement of the volunteers. 



On a larger scale this project strongly promotes intercultural understanding and European awareness within the local Icelandic communities and among the hundreds of volunteers participating in the camps.



This project encourages people to challenge their stereotypes of other cultures.  It promotes intercultural awareness on an international level, as the participants in our workcamps come from a broad international background. 



By promoting tolerance and reflection on our diversity of values, as well as promoting the values and skills for cooperation and earth protection, this project seeks to inspire both the international volunteers and the local Icelandic communities involved.
Le volontariat, formation à la tolérance et à la citoyenneté européenne

Our project will enable young Europeans to experience  the real social Europe and assist by their presence in a country that is not theirs, the host organization but also other people of all age to build a true European consciousness.The objectives of our project  :- Promote the construction of a social Europe, taking particular account of the vulnerable groups in difficulties, and also awakens the consciousness to environmental protection ,- Promote European and international exchanges to develop shared experiences of solidarity and meeting the world's cultures as training tolerance and active citizenship.This project enables at 5 volunteers from Germany, United Kingdom, and Spain from 18 to 23 years old, to do a European Voluntary Service in France, in Strasbourg, in Scherwiller and in Niederbronn-les-Bains from 01/09/2016 to 20/08/2017. They will bring their help in organisations which accompanying people and children in social difficulties, and in a cross-border youth hostel.Different tasks will be proposed to volunteers : hosting people, help on workshops, on daily and administrativ tasks...Young volunteers will be followed by sending organisations : IJGD, Deses3,  ICYE UK and ICE-D and a coordinating organisation : ICE-RF.ICE-RF organises a two week preparation in august 2016 at Niederbronn-les-Bains and others seminars in differents regions of France, one in november 2016 and one in avril/may 2017. Each structure has precise missions, inspired by the Erasmus+ guide.Results and impacts expected are :for volunteers, affirm their will to be engaged,  increase their social and linguistic culture, enable them to be aware of their competencies. for organisations, enable them to continue to host and send volunteers,for the focussed public, enable them to do exchange  with people from other culture and to show an example of realised project.Potential long term advantages are to make of this volunteers and this structures examples of well european exchanges, and  that other young people and structures do this type of project.
Shaken, not stirred - How to enrich the European sense of belonging through international youth work

Intercultural learning has been the objective target of international youth work since more than two decades. The aims of international youth encounters are often defined as providing young people the opportunity to get to know other countries, societies and cultures. By doing so the participants will be given the chance to learn about the “others”, to question and to reduce stereotypes and to learn about himself/ herself. Yet the concept of intercultural learning often applies to the idea of one homogenic national culture, not considering the plurality and diversity of each country.In the training course “Shaken, not Stirred! How to enrich the European sense of belonging through international youth work” we aim at providing a fresh outlook on the mix of modern European societies, looking at the multiple influences they are subject to, while exploring ways of introducing the concept of multiple influences and identities at all levels into the international youth work. we would like to involve 32 youth workers and 16 associations in a training that will be dedicated to presenting, discussing, exchanging and developing tools and methods for anti-discrimination, anti-bias education and social inclusion. At the same time the training will present the concept of cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue as defined by UNESCO and the relevant European texts of reference such as the Council of Europe’s Whitebook.The methods will be based on self-reflection and case studies as a starting point in order to render the theoretic discussions relevant and usable for the concrete context the participants are experiencing. The programme will be based on interactive and participative methods.The anticipated outcomes of the training course are to devise practices of how international youth work can contribute to the challenges related to the plural life style of each individual in a diverse society, opening the eyes of the youngsters for the diversity and plurality, but also the discrimination and social exclusion existing within their own country. The goal is to provide a platform for youngsters from different backgrounds to find out more about diversity, to affect a general sensibility, respect, responsibility for fighting against discrimination, understanding among the people and to foster awareness of the added positive value of cultural diversity. Furthermore we want to focus on how to contribute to the social inclusion of disadvantaged groups in our societies through international youth work.
Solidary Europe: online micro-funding to build a better future

The Help Freely Foundation uses new technologies for innovative and social purposes, giving a hand to thousands of Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) all over the world thanks to a multiplier effect which converts small actions into visible results on a larger level. This happens though different web tools that enable solidary shops to donate a percentage of their profits to the NGOs that users themselves choose. One of the main objectives of the project is to establish a global network of Cooperation between users, businesses, the media and NGOs which allows each member to benefit from the others.

Furthermore, the aim of this first project is to promote social entrepreneurship and partnerships, active citizenship and volunteering, non-formal education, cultural exchanges and youth employment. There are 7 organizations taking part in this project. The Help Freely Foundation will have a coordinating role, while the other 6 organizations (Akzente from Austria, Scambi Europei from Italy, Concordia Rhône-Alpes from France, ICYE from UK, Kumulus from Sweden and Centro cultural de Hispanohablantes from the Netherlands) will send one volunteer each.

The volunteers will work at the Help Freely Foundation's Headquarters, located in downtown Las Palmas de Gran Canaria. However, their work here will have a worldwide impact and will encompass several fields, languages and cultures. The global perspective of our projects will allow the volunteers to choose their own fields of action and, permanently supported by our staff, to feel the satisfaction to see their input have large-scale social impact.

The volunteers will have the chance of developing themselves in the preferred areas thanks to the task diversity and our staff's open character. Since we count on many experts among our staff members, we are in a position to excellently train the volunteers in several areas. First of all, the volunteers will go through a general training on the nonprofit digital marketing and the Help Freely Foundation's mission, apart from a cultural and linguistic introduction. After this period, the volunteers will learn more specifically about the technical deeds of digital marketing.

The volunteers will be hosted in a shared flat nearby the office, so that they can easily walk home. Both the house and the office are located in downtown Las Palmas, really close to the beach and strategically connected with the rest of the city and the island by bus.


SELECTION PROCESS AND CRITERIA
We believe that human factor is most valuable in any project. Therefore, our selection process is based in the worth and attitude of the volunteers, in their eagerness and enthusiasm, regardless their origin, culture and background.

The Help Freely Foundation will be happy to host those volunteers who are as eager as we are to be part of this project. What we are looking for are committed, responsible, open-minded young individuals who are willing to learn and innovate, regardless their nationality, genre, sexual or political orientation, ethnic group, race or physical aspect.
 
We want the volunteers to enrich us with their experiences and cultural backgrounds; we want them to inspire local youngsters to follow their examples and take an active role in Europe. We believe that human factor is most valuable in any project and we know that every selected volunteer will contribute to our mission in a surprising and innovative way.

TASKS
- Contacting solidary marketing partners worldwide.
- Managing marketing accounts for our partners.
- Looking for new nonprofit strategic partnerships.
- Offering digital support to our solidary partner shops and NGOs.
- Taking care of the digital campaigns for our solidary partners.
- Community Management (project dissemination)
- Taking part in outdoors volunteering activities in the city.

All activities will be supervised by our staff and mentors. The volunteers will be properly trained and will never be individually held responsible for these tasks. The volunteers will work 6 hours a day from Monday to Friday, but this working hours will include enough time for their evaluations, language course, personal project and project dissemination.

The voluntees' participation in our project will be most valuable since it'll magnify our multiplying effect and our European dimension. They will be the nex between the Foundation and its worldwide solidary partners and they will help establish a long-term stable cooperative network to support social projects and iniciatives in several countries. Moreover, they will have the chance to develop themselves personally and professionally, increasing their employability. Finally, the volunteers' presence in our local community will result on a valuable interaction with the local youngsters, who will get closer to the European reality and discover a new world of possibilities to better their future.

The EVS volunteers will contribute to the preparations and the implementation of the travelling exhibition “Anne Frank – A History for Today” and its related programme of activities, such as the project "Anne Frank Ambassadors" . The Anne Frank exhibition focusses on the story of Anne Frank, the historical context of her time and the relevance of this history for today’s world. Copies of the exhibition tour in 40 countries. Its educational programme is based on the concept of 'peer education': young people themselves are responsible for the guided tours.
The EVS volunteers will mainly deal with presentations of the exhibition in the Netherlands. In the framework of the 2015 EVS project,  the exhibition will be shown on at least five locations in the Netherlands. Using  standard materials, the volunteers will assist the local organisers of the exhibition. On location the volunteers will help the exhibition guides (usually young people aged 15 – 18) to fulfill their tasks; the volunteers will contribute to the training of the guides, they will be in permanent contact with them and at the end of the exhibition presentation they will organise the evaluation with the guides and report back to the project coordinator at the Anne Frank House.
The volunteers will also contribute to a new project called "Anne Frank Ambassadors". This is an initiative by the Anne Frank House to actively maintain the network of former peer guides in the Netherlands and abroad. The guides connect through dedicated webpages and they are offered to take part in follow-up activities; some of them will be selected to take part in a youth meeting that will be modelled after the first "International Youth Conference" that took place in the Anne Frank House in August 2014.

The project aims to promote the social inclusion of young people, who are very often unemployed. This project encourages young people from around Europe to participate in education and the labour market.

Located in the east of the Czech Republic, Kromeriz, Klubicko Kromeriz is a center for the joint meeting of families with children. Parent Center offers community space, education, counselling and recreational activities.
The project is focused primarily on the target group of children and youth, as well as their parents and the general public, to promote cultural, language and sports education.
Klubicko is an accredited hosting organization. We are looking for volunteers who are interested in working primarily with preschool children (3-6 years) within EVS for 12 months.
The project aims at mutual enrichment, acquiring new competencies and skills for volunteers. Children and adults alike will gain a positive attitude towards other cultures, opinions and ideas.  We hope to also hope to give them interest in further education. This project really applies the Erasmus+ motto: "Changing lives. Opening minds".
Volunteers will participate in Klubicko programs and activities, but will also be able to participate in the partner organizations projects which generally take place in local primary schools, secondary schools, grammar schools and the library.
The volunteer will always be guided by the trainer. They will be motivated for independent work in leadership activities that they will have the opportunity to choose. They will also be motivated to implement new ideas and activities.
Activities in which volunteers would be able to engage: English nursery, kindergarten with Montessori elements, sports, dance and art activities, teaching English and French, suburban camps, tourist activities for families, clubs for parents and children with special needs, one-off activities with a cultural or sporting focus, open clubs for teenagers, miniproject representing their country or this one, teaching about the language and culture of volunteer etc.
Volunteers will be encouraged and taught to introduce in appropriate form for children, families and the local community, their culture, language, traditions and any other aspects of life in their country of origin.
Be The Change - Training Seminar on diversity-oriented change management

As a consequence to the heated debate about immigration, racism has made its way more and more into mainstream society undermining basic values of diversity and tolerance to be conveyed to young people by their social environment. As a consequence, xenophobic attitudes, discrimination against people with different identities and open racism have become a sad reality in schools and other places where young people of diverse backgrounds interact. Given this situation the partners in this project are convinced that European youth NGOs have to play a more active role in detecting and combatting intolerant, discriminatory and racist behavior in their own organization and the environments they are working in and look for answers to the following questions: How can we make a difference given the current challenge of increasing racism and discrimination against people of diverse background? What kind of changes are needed at structural and operational level to support organizations taking clear positions and displaying coherent behavior? How can we start reflective processes and pursue respective change in our organizations? Which processes lead to success? 

Against this background and in support of the Paris declaration of EU Education Ministers 3 years ago, the overarching aim of the project "Be the change" is to ensure that young people acquire social, civic and intercultural competences by promoting democratic values and fundamental rights, social inclusion and non-discrimination, as well as active citizenship. This will be done by enhancing the management, governance, innovation capacity and diversity-oriented approach of youth organisations in 11 EU countries and in Russia, providing them with tools and strategies for racism-critical and diversity-oriented change management. The project was developed as an accompanying measure in the frame of the “STAR E” Strategic Partnership Project (https://stareurope.wordpress.com/) which is being implemented by ICJA with 8 partner organizations from 2017 – 2020. 

Main project activity of the project "Be the Change" is a 5 day Training Seminar on diversity-oriented change management  which will take place in Berlin in February 2019 and will involve 23 participants from 12 youth organizations in Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Poland, Russia, Slovakia and United Kingdom. The training programme was developed by a group of partners of the STAR E project under the guidance of two trainers of the expert organization SOCIUS in Berlin. All Partners (except SOCIUS) can count on many years of experience in international youth exchange and voluntary service programs and non-formal education in particular aiming at the inclusion of minorities and vulnerable target groups and promotion of non formal peace and diversity oriented education for young people.They recognised the need to develop concrete actions and make adjustments to their organisations in order to correspond to the challenges posed by the increasingly violent racism and to strengthen their role as facilitators of inclusion and promotors of diversity. 

After the seminar the 23 participants within their organizations are expected to devise adapted strategies to introduce and accompany change in their organizations. They will be more aware about practices of racism and discrimination in their work and organization and what they can do about it and able to apply tools and methods which have sustainable influence on their organization’s sensitivity towards diversity as well as capacity to facilitate inclusion.The main innovative element is that the training sessions will constantly inter-relate the values of diversity-orientation, anti-discrimination and inclusion with the learning about change management in youth NGOs and thus will have a direct impact on the management and activities of the participating organisations.  

The training report will be published and it is expected that it will inspire other youth organizations to undertake and manage diversity-oriented and like-minded change processes which will increase the quality of youth work in Europe in the longer term.
Youth Work Can Unite: Merging Parallel Realities in Europe

Context
Europe is facing one of the most trying moments in recent history: The ongoing arrival of large numbers of refugees at the European borders, political and financial instability in many nation-states and the aftermath of a number of terrorist attacks in the past year - to name a few. Fear, anxiety and resentment within communities is fuelling political rhetoric and populist discourse on refugees and migration in general, leading to minorities being targeted. It is now more important than ever to challenge a narrative in which refugees, migrants and minorities are a danger to European society. The main objective of this project, which aims at creating unity within diversity, is to exchange ideas, create a vision and strategies to counter racism and to offer support to refugees and NGOs. The training gives project partners the opportunity to come together to gain new skills in anti-racism and to tackle hate speech, to gain and share knowledge, ideas and best practice on diverse refugee issues, and to outline a Europe-wide and individual organisational strategy that charts actions to be undertaken in the near future. 

Main objectives 
1. Provide training on anti-racism, anti-nationalism and tackling hate speech.
2. Share and discuss knowledge on the situation of refugees in the participating countries
3. Share ideas and best practice to challenge populist discourse on refugees and migrants and to promote inclusion and diversity in Europe 
4. Map challenges and outline a strategic plan of actions that support and raise awareness of the situation of refugees and foster inclusion and strengthen diversity.

The participants
The project includes 25 participants from 12 countries in the EU (Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Iceland, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Russian Federation, Slovakia and United Kingdom). Profile of participants includes: Experience in long-term international volunteering, direct or indirect experience working with refugees and/or on refugee issues, and experience in anti-racism education, its methodology and approach. The interest, time and motivation to work with and on refugee issues over the next two-years will play a role. Youth workers with migrant backgrounds and refugees will be given priority. 

Main activities 
The project's main activity is the training for youth workers, staff members, trainers active in the field of youth and voluntary work. It will focus on sharing knowledge on refugees issues and training to address racism, promote inclusion and strengthen diversity. It will open up space and time to share ideas and best practice to develop an Europe-wide and individual partner strategic action plan for the foreseeable future. 

Methodology
The project and training will be based on non-formal learning and participatory approaches, offering spaces for joint work and sharing of knowledge and skills. The methods of the training will include group discussions, debates, workshops, simulations, presentations, political cafés, icebreakers, sharing good practices, etc. The underlying philosophy is that of intercultural dialogue, understanding and respect, which will form the basis of all interactions and discussions, strategies and tools that emerge from it. 

Expected results 
1. Knowledge of different perspectives on the situation of refugees, facts on migration and asylum in Europe versus media narrative.
2. New and effective methods for challenging narratives on refugees, raising awareness and addressing racism, xenophobia and hate speech.
3. Develop a strategic Europe-wide and individual organisational action plan for implementation after the training.
4. The Final Activity Report describing the process, flow, structure, content and methodology of the training. 
5. Network, strengthen ties and build new relationships for an antiracist movement in Europe that provides support to refugees and NGOs working with refugees. 

Impact
-Building capacity of youth workers and staff in long-term strategic planning, anti-racism and refugee issues.
-Strengthening partnerships in the EU, new collaborations with NGOs and other youth and volunteering NGOs. 
-Young volunteers will gain transversal skills through the hands-on support they provide to the implementation of local actions.

Long-term benefits
-Young refugees will receive much-needed support, interaction with peer groups will support their integration. 
-NGOs working with refugees will receive much-needed support and become part of the network of EVS and ICYE volunteering host organisations.
-The Europe-wide strategy and action plan will serve policy development for the ICYE European region on refugee issues and future projects on the topic.

CirKus-Kus, the first school of new circus is a NGO  that has been founded by young and active team of professionals. 
We consider ourselves to be a part of the Slovakias active society. 
We want to change not working things and create new great, useful and functional concepts and modules. 
We are all ex university students, educated in the field of study we are working in now. The core team members are graduates of: 
-MANAGEMENT: Management in Culture+Service Science, management and engineering
-SPORT: Motoric Sciences + Circus Pedagogy
-PSYCHOLOGY: PE+psychology
-ART: Puppetry and scenic arts

Geographical context: most of the activities will take place in Bratislava, the capital city of Slovakia. It is very probable that several one-time activities will be held in other Slovak cities or in the neighbor countries.
Local community: The organization is working with vast community. From 2 years old kids and kindergartens, elementary schools, youth, teenagers, adults, families up to seniors and socially disadvantaged groups. Main focus of our activities is on kids, youth and families. 
The activities will often take place in Bratislava cultural houses and centers, kindergartens, schools, universities, theaters, festivals, parks, on public and private events.  
We have started the first project of Social Circus in Slovakia, where we are working with various socially disadvantaged groups of people. Especially socially disadvantaged kids and youth from orphanages, poor families, roma or immigrant kids. 

We are looking for motivated, active and creative young people who like to work with kids, youth, adults and socially disadvantaged groups. The future volunteers should have interest in working with kids, culture and art - theatre, circus or other related arts,
Volunteers will co-work with professional supervisors - drama and circus trainers and lecturers, project and event managers (all English speakers).

Incoming volunteers will help the organization with youth circus and social circus training programs and related activities. They will be involved in the preparation, organization and executive process of our courses, workshops and performances. 
They will gain or develop skills in many aspects and domains of project management, including project planning and designing, event planning and management, working with children and youngsters. EVS volunteers will also take part in various administration and creative tasks, including fundraising, or communication and marketing issues, (for example updating our website or organizing a promotion event with continuous support of our staff).
Volunteers will help our team with preparation, organization and execution of new circus and theater classes for children, youngsters and adults. This will be the core of the activities. Activities as: training children, helping our staff with some basic acrobatic lessons and trainings, creating basic equipment for new circus needs (juggling tools), helping with basic costume creation and other small helping works.
They will also assist in preparation, organization and execution of temporary activities of CirKus-Kus, such as performances, workshops, social circus projects, cultural/educational/sportive projects with local communities, outdoor activities, happenings, kids camps, participation on festivals and others.
Volunteers will have an opportunity to design and create their own small project (small show, event, cultural/educational/sportive  activity, workshop..) In this small project volunteers can fully show their special skills, abilities and knowledge and contribute in the mutual learning process. Each of the sides (not only the volunteers but also the hosting organization team), will get to know new domains and obtain new experience and skills. 
Very important part in the learning process will be sharing, discussing and evaluating of volunteers plans, ideas and visions through continuous dialogue with the other team members. In this process volunteers will receive an important feedback from the team and vice-versa.

Expected learning outcomes: 
- working with children, youngsters and adults of different age
- working with socially disadvantaged kids and youth
- soft skill and social competencies development (teamwork, cooperation, planning, risk management, communication, creativity..)
- pedagogic skills development (learning how to lead circus, theatre classes)
- artistic, dramaturgic, scenographic skills development (learning how to make a show)
- new circus skills and techniques learning (juggling, acrobatics, gymnastics..)
- project and event management skills development (learning how to make a project)
- broader understanding of different cultures and nations, nurturing tolerance and open mindedness
- language and cultural skills. The volunteers will also improve their English skills.
- learning about Youth in Action program and international projects
- certification of acquired skills through the Youthpass scheme
Youth and Social Media as Agents of Peace

On one hand the dynamic development of social networks and media offers new opportunities to include more and more young people in youth NGO activities as well as international voluntary service programmes and youth exchange which may contribute to building a social media community and foster solidarity at global level. On the other hand the increasingly rapid development of new digital communication tools and internet contents poses challenges to organisations and youth workers (many of whom still grew up  with less exposure to the digital world). The challenge is to stay authentic when using social media to reach out to or communicate with young people. According to the analysis of a majority of partner organisations of ICJA e.V. there is a big need to improve the training of youth workers in the field Social Media and to develop joint communication strategies. Against this background the project “Youth and Social Media as agents of Peace” was developed to increase the social media competence of 20 youth workers from 11 different EU countries and the neighboring partner country Russian Federation. In accordance with Priority E of the European Union Work Plan for Youth for 2016-2018, a resolution  passed by the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council on 23-24 November 2015, the participating youth workers  shall be trained to recognize the opportunities and challenges of new communication trends of young people and elaborate new and appealing communication strategies to involve more young people in non formal education and voluntary service programmes, to foster their active citizenship and contribute to unfold their potential and talents in order to maximize the impact of youth work at European level. The training will take place from 01.-05. November 2016 in Berlin.  18 staff and volunteer youth workers of non-profit youth and voluntary service organizations from 10 EU and one neighboring partner country ( Russian Federation) will analyze the variety of functions and best practice in making use of social media and will be trained in three competence areas: 1) Getting to know and applying social media 2) Conditions for successful use of social media and 3) Elaborating and implementing tailor-made social media strategies in the field of international voluntary service, youth exchange and peace and democracy education.  At the end of the training the participants will be able to develop efficient communication strategies making use of social media and to implement these within their organisations’ youth activities. They will not only pursue the aim to disseminate their programme offers but will be able to combine these efforts with the aim to cater to the educational and information needs of young people and to foster their active citizenship. They will be able to use networks and communication channels which are appealing for the programme particants and motivate them to engage in voluntary action for societal changes. By connecting the people dealing with communication in the participating organizations and developing joint social media strategies the project will have a longterm impact on the participating youth workers and their capacity to work together to achieve higher visibility of their youth work activities at European level.  By elaborating and disseminating a documentation of the elaborated strategies in Online-networks these can be further used and disseminated. Thus the project will contribute to a better quality of youth work at European level.

“Human Rights Cafe ” is a space for volunteers and young people to become active global and European citizens by transforming issues of local and global importance to concrete action and change-making.
For 6 months in Helsingør, Denmark, two young volunteers from the United Kingdom and Poland will do volunteer work in order to gain work experience in the fields of youth work, active citizenship and non formal education, environment and climate change, event making, facilitation and conducting workshops on human rights, global citizenship, intercultural communication and lifelong learning while they enhance their personal and professional development and empowerment, giving them abilities in areas that will make them well-prepared for their future lives and enhancing their employability.
The aim of the project is enable young people to raise their awareness of current pressing issues of intercultural coexistence, environment and climate change, human rights, lifelong learning, active youth participation, respect for diversity, the use of non formal education and project management. The project will make members of the local community feel more integrated and eager to cooperate in terms of local volunteering and active participation thereby enhancing synergies on a local level. Young people, the participants of cultural workshops and activities, will be more aware of cultural differences, human rights and environmental issues, laying the foundation for their future as active European citizens who will have the potential to impact society locally and globally.
By selecting two young young people with a diverse range of cultural, educational and professional backgrounds, we hope and trust that this will help the youth enhance the project objectives while the project at the same time will promote Erasmus+ (especially EVS) program among Danish and international EVS youth and beyond.

Venue: Klosterneuburg, Dates 1.1.2017-31.12.2017
Countries involved: UK, Austria, 
Sending partner ICYE UK
Coordinator Grenzenlos Austria, 
Host organisation Wohnheim St Martin

Within the project “ Wohnheim St.Martin international “ the Wohnheim St Martin, a living place for disabled adults in Klosterneuburg intends to host 1 EVS volunteer for 12 months in 2017
The main objectives for all involved organizations:

+ get new inputs and broaden the organisational horizon
+ receive intercultural and foreign language input through hosting an European volunteer
+ Stregthen partnerships through a concrete EVS activity
+ support and give recognition to social institutions working with disbaled clients
+promote volunteering as an added value within society

Wohnheim St.Martin has been involved in EVS activities since EVS started and shared that an important impact by EVS volunteers could have been measured on their clients.

The project is coordinated by Grenzenlos. Volunteers are connected with other EVS volunteers living in Vienna and surrounding and are invited to take part in monthly meetings and organized free time activities on a voluntarly base. 

The general learning outcomes of the project are 
+ to develop Social and Civic competences, such as team work, empathy, especially competences related with the relation with other people, about living together, about discovering themselves in different context. 
+ to promote cultural awareness through international exchange and through the exchange with other EVS volunteers
+ to discover the social system in Austria through volunteering in institutions dealing with disabled clients in Klosterneuburg
+to  improve their organizational and teamwork skills as a result of a close co-operation with the team members and being part of team meetings
+Creative skills –through the opportunity to prepare workshops such as sport activities, cultural activities for the disabled clients
+Entrepreneurship through offering own activities depending on the personality of the volunteer to the kids Volunteers are encouraged to bring their own ideas into their host projects but also to the Grenzenlos EVS activities. They will have to create, plan and evaluate an activity on their own
+ Living in Austria with the support of the German classes will give the participants the chance to increase their competences in foreign languages, specially German, but also the languages of other volunteers, the clients of the projects and English.
+to develop own “Learning to learn” competences.
PROJECT-SPECIFIC LEARNING OUTCOMES Wohnheim St.Martin
+ to get to know different working methods (Montessori, theatre pedagogic, etc) in the work with disabled adults
+to get an insight view in a living and workplace for disabled adults
+ to gain a better geographical, political and social knowledge of Austria and Klosterneuburg and Vienna specifically
+Organizational and group-management skills developed through planning and supervising little activities for disabled clients
+ And last but not least, within the frame work of the Grenzenlos EVS programme and all its events, free time possibilities, general interactions with other volunteers and the people of the Grenzenlos-environment, volunteers will experience how to appreciate and how to learn from and within an intercultural landscape.

This project is based on a strong existing partnership between the two organisations involved, ICYE-UK and Lastochki and follows on from previous successful EVS projects.  This project involves one young person from the UK taking part in a 11-month European Voluntary Service in Samara in the Russian Federation (partner country)
The sending and receiving organisations' work focuses on promoting intercultural awareness through international mobility and volunteering.  The participant in this project will have an active role in the receiving organisation which will allow for their involvement in a wide range of different tasks and activities and provide a positive non-formal learning experience. The participant will bring a new cultural perspective to the work of the receiving organisation and will also have the opportunity to learn about Russian culture, traditions, values and ways of life. The project is also designed to provide the opportunity for intercultural dialogue between the participant, other international volunteers in Samara, members of the receiving organisation and the local community allowing for increased cultural and European awareness for all those involved.  It is therefore expected that the project will be of mutual benefit for all those involved and will directly contribute towards the aims of the sending and receiving organisations by further promoting intercultural learning and active citizenship through voluntary service to a wider audience.
EVS im Montessori Kinderhaus im IBZ, 2011-DE-10 - 2

The meeting with European volunteers will open a vivid insight for the children of the Montessori kindergarden in the IBZ into concepts such as cultural differences , intercultural learning and being different . The volunteer will bring knowledge , customs, and ways of life from their home countries that can enrich life with the kids in the kindergarden and that can be an inducement to deal with these aspects of life. The children together with the volunteers and the workers of the kindergarden can experience and develop many new perspectives. Thus the European volunteers will help to bring people in and around the nursery together and make Europe stand a little closer together.
An essential component of the EFD is the non formal learning , which is also a big part of the program in the institution. The volunteers will not only have the chance to exchange cultural knowledge, but also due to the montessori pedagogics will find structures in the kindergarden, that explicitly promote a natural and non -formal learning.
The two volunteers are closely involved in the team of the kindergarten and thus take an active part in shaping the free learning process. In contact with their environment, the children make their own (learning) experiences . Since each learning-material is only available once, the children are encouraged to communicate with each other . The volunteers together with the workers accompany the children in these experiences and will be available to share personal experiences.
Depending on their interests the volunteers may also develop their own projects or provide ideas for these. In addition, they can also be included as mothertongues of a foreign language and be available for communicating in another language. This is especially interessting, since the Montessori kindergarden in the IBZ is following a bilingual concept and is working with children from different cultural backgrounds.
The Montessori kindergarten in the IBZ promotes international exchange and understanding of cultural differences , social conditions , traditions and perspectives. It allows volunteers with civic engagement to revive the idea of a European neighborhood to develop sympathies and reflect on the idea of each other. It offers an opportunity to cross-regional mobility , work experience , personal development and the acquisition of key skills through informal education.

Poglej naokrog! (mladinske akcije v javnem prostoru)

EVS volunteer will be actively involved in one or more projects of KUD Ljud, which mainly revolve around the questions of accessibility of art in public spaces and through it builds community beyond racism, prejudice, cultivating tolerance and promotes peaceful solving of the conflicts. 

Working tasks of the volunteer will touch upon various aspects of theatrical production in public spaces. A volunteer will gain and/or deepen his/her knowledge in the following areas: various acting and directing techniques; leading workshops for amateurs actors; design of light, sound and picture; organizational work (financial, executional and other levels of organization of an artistic event in a public space); active participation in theatre events in diverse functions (assistant, scenography and costume design, make-up artist, performer, organizer..) etc.. 
Area of work will be agreed upon after a consultation between volunteer, mentor and other members of the association in order to suit the wishes, ambitions and interests of a volunteer at best. Besides the before mentioned fields of skill and knowledge gaining, a volunteer will also gain informal skills in group work, working independence, self-initiative, become responsible and patient. The volunteer will also have the opportunity and support to work alone and to learn how transform ideas into practice.
Volunteer will be encouraged to use gained knowledge and skills also after the end of the project in his home environment.

It is anticipated the work will take 6 to 7 hours/day, five days/week (Monday - Friday). Work will partially take place in the office of the  association and partly at other locations within the city (where acting rehearsals, public actions etc. will take place – Museum of Contemporary Arts, venues of the performances, public space etc.). We will offer to the volunteer experience to participate at least once on international theatre event outside of Slovenia (Theatre festival or a conference). Through the project the volunteer will cooperate with local community, especially with local youth.
One EVS volunteer from UK is to be selected for period of 6 months.
Cross Cultural Engagement at Parus Nadezhdy

The project involves one young person from the UK taking part in a European Voluntary Service project for 6 months with Parus Nadezhdy, an NGO based in Samara in Russia aiming at providing integration of the disabled children of Samara region into society and to promoting the ideas of independent life philosophy and social approach to disability.The participant will be actively involved with the work of the receiving organisation, interacting with the disabled children in the organisation or at home, to help them accomplish day to day tasks (eat, walk, etc.). He will also help the children develop their creative and intellectual abilities and propose them activities such as painting, reading, drama, sports, etc.The volunteer will also be involved in the preparation and organisation of regular events, run by the centre: seminars, training for parents, festivals for children, etc. Moreover the volunteers will be encourage to initiate any kind of activity together with children in accordance with his centres of interest. This project provides a young person who wishes to discover Russia, learn a new language, work with disabled children and take initiatives, etc. with an excellent opportunity to achieve these aims.During the project it is expected that he will develop new social and personal skills, as well as practical knowledge and experiences which will help him in his future career. The project will also provide an invaluable intercultural dimension to the work of the receiving organisation and to the lives of its beneficiaries.  Through the practical support, enthusiasm and energy bought by the participant it is expected that the project will give added value to the work of the host organisation and provide a contribution towards their aim of improving social inclusion for people with disabilities in Russia.
